title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.17.1 | 12-02-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Om Agyana Timiran Dhasya Gyananj Nishalakaya
Chakshurun Militam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Namao Vishnu Padaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale
Shri Mate Bhakti Vedanta Swamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine
Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Pashchatya Deshatarine
Jai Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda
Shri Advaita Gadadhara Shri Vasadi Gaurabhakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare
Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya
Narayanam Namaskritya Naramchaiva Narottamam
Deveem Saraswateem Vyasam Tatojayam Udi Rayet
In this session,
we will be talking about the
we will be discussing from the first verse of the seventeenth chapter
of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam
this is a new chapter we are beginning
this seventeenth chapter of the first canto is entitled
punishment and reward of Kali
in the previous chapter it was described
how
when Pariksit was ruling
Kali Purusha
was trying to enter his kingdom
and how Pariksit dealt with the
Pariksit's plans
and none of the Pulipurusya won't be described in this chapter
Suth Def Kari Purusha
Tatra Go Mithunam Raja
Hanyamanam Anathavat
Dandahastamche Vrishalam
Dadrishhe Nripalanchanam
The meaning of this verse is
Suta Goswami said
After reaching that place
Maharaja Pariksit observes that
Maharaj Pariksit observes that
that a lower caste Shudra dressed like a king was beating a cow and a bull with a
club as if they had no owner so the previous chapter ended with the
description that while the while Mother Earth and the personality of religious
principles Dharma, Dharini and Dharma were engaged in conversation the saintly
king Pariksit reached that place and now the description continues what did
Pariksit observe when he reached that place he saw that this Kali Purusha
that this Kali Purusha
he is dressed like a king but actually he doesn't have the qualification of a
king he is not a qualified Kshatriya according to the Vedic understanding he
is actually unqualified person but he is dressed like a king means he is trying
to occupy the post of the
ruler or the or the King without qualification and it was also very clear
that the Kshatriyas are meant for protecting the citizens and the domestic
animals but here we see this person he is dressed like a king and then he is dressed like a king.
dressed like a king but he is beating a cow and a bull as if they had no owner
so Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport what does this mean for us who
are living in Kali Yuga it has got a lot of significance this description here
the principal sign Srila Prabhupada says in the purport the principal sign of the
age of Kali is that lower caste's shudras, what does it mean lower caste shudras
men withoutersonical culture and men without spiritual initiation
would be dressed like administrators or Kings and the
principal business of such non-Ksatria rulers would be to kill the
investors.
Innocent animals, especially the cows and bulls, who shall be unprotected by their masters,
the bona fide vices, the mercantile community.
Sushila Prabhupada clearly explains a often misunderstood terminology.
In the Vedic scriptures, in the description of the varana and ashrama system of dharma,
it is described that the society should be divided according to occupational duties and
according to spiritual development into four varanas and four ashramas, four social orders
and four spiritual orders.
Now, this varana classification has become completely topsy-turvy in this Kali Yuga because
of the misunderstanding that one belongs to a varana according to birth in a certain family,
which is not.
What is explained in the scriptures, clearly in the Bhagavad Gita, Krishna says,
the quality based on qualifications, based on the qualities possessed by a person,
that person should be classified according to the qualities and according to the
occupational duties.
The one who performs the same occupation according to the work he performs, according to the
natural inclination to work in a certain way, a person should actually be classified
as a brahmana, kshatriya, vaishya or shudra.
So very clearly who are to be classified as shudras, those who do not have brahmanical
culture and they do not have spiritual initiation.
Sushila Prabhupada explains.
That means they are more or less godless people and they are bereft of the brahmanical culture. They are uncultured. According to Vedic description, they are uncultured.
So, uncultured, godless people are to be classified as Shudras. Not according to birth. Regardless of which type of family they take birth in, it doesn't matter.
If they are uncultured, if they are godless, then they are to be classified as Shudras.
Such people will be considered as Shudras.
They will be dressed like administrators or kings.
This is the sign of Kalyuga.
And these administrators who are unqualified, but somehow they have managed to occupy the post of the administrator.
They will simply indulge in killing innocent animals.
Especially the cow and the bull.
And these cows and bulls will be killed by such unqualified administrators.
Because such cows and bulls which are meant to be protected by the Vaishya class, the mercantile community in the Vedic culture.
These animals will be unprotected.
They will be unprotected.
So, therefore these administrators can freely kill without anybody questioning them.
Without the animals, innocent animals who give lot of service to the human society, not getting any protection.
They are helpless.
They are innocent. They are helpless.
So, this is the situation.
Even in this age of Kali, that we are finding it right now in our present times.
Exact description given in the Srimad Bhagavatam.
So, Srila Prabhupada further says,
In the Bhagavad Gita, in the 18th chapter, in the 44th verse, it is said,
that the Vaishyas are meant to deal in agriculture, cow protection and trade.
Krishi, Goraksha, Vaanijjam, Vaishya, Karma, Swabhavajam.
By their acquired nature.
There are certain class of people in the civilized human society who are meant to deal in three things.
Krishi or agriculture.
Goraksha, cow protection.
Goraksha.
And Vaanijja, trade, commerce.
So, the cow protection was specifically entrusted to the Vaishyas in the Vedic culture.
Now, there are no qualified Vaishyas.
So, therefore, the cows are not getting the protection that they deserve.
And in this age of Kali, the degraded Vaishyas, the mercantile men,
are engaged in supplying cows to slaughterhouses.
As long as the cow gives milk, they keep the cow and take the milk and do business with milk and milk products.
And when the cow stops giving milk, send it to the slaughterhouse.
This is their business.
Not that the cow has given so much service and it should be given protection.
No such consideration at all.
Merciless, heartless, cruel people.
Very, very mean-minded.
Right?
Yes.
And it is said in the scriptures that the Kshatriyas, the qualified Kshatriyas,
are meant to protect the citizens of the state.
Whereas the Vaishyas are meant to protect the cows and bulls
and utilize them to produce grains and milk.
So, both the humans and the cows and bulls require protection.
Because human form of life is very, very important
for it affords the opportunity for self-realization.
And cows and bulls are especially meant for producing grains and milk.
And the cow gives a lot of service.
Every part of the cow is very, very useful.
Even the cow, the urine and stool of the cow is very useful for human society.
Goarka.
Cow urine is called Goarka.
It has got a lot of medicinal properties.
It can be used in so many ways.
So many useful ways for human beings.
And the cow dung is first-class medicine.
It is first-class manure.
It is the best fuel for dried cow dung cakes.
And it helps in so many ways.
So many ways the cow dung can be used.
It has got antiseptic properties.
When cow dung cake, dried cake is burnt,
it drives away mosquitoes.
That smoke drives away mosquitoes.
So like that, there are innumerable benefits of cow dung and cow urine.
Such an animal is very, very, very useful.
After the cow dies a natural death,
the horn of the cow, the horns of the cow are very useful.
The skin of the cow is very useful.
Very useful also.
So cow is so valuable.
The cow tail, the tail of the cow is also very useful.
So like this, the cow is such a useful animal.
And most importantly, the cow gives us milk,
which is the most precious food substance for human beings,
especially for human beings.
So such animals should never be killed.
Should never be killed.
So that is the Vedic injunction.
And it is the greatest sin to kill the cow.
Gohatya is the greatest sin.
And people have to suffer in very horrible ways
by the laws of nature imposed on such foolish people,
ignorant people, merciless people, cruel people.
By nature, by God, through the material nature,
this punishment will be enforced.
People have to suffer.
So I will stop here.
Thank you very much.
Hare Krishna.
